course_name: Cult/civ of Cent Eur: Prehistoric to 350 Ce
course_description: Cultural development of Central Europe from the earliest stone and pottery cultures, through the Bronze, Iron and Celtic Ages, ending with the Gallo-Roman period. Beliefs and practices, material objects, artistic developments, and architecture. Digitized images are used to illustrate the cultural evidence.
prerequisites: Notes: given in English. This course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

instructor:
Blended:
A blended (hybrid) course is a learning environment where face-to-face teaching time is reduced, but not eliminated, to allow students more time for online study. The online component is normally 50% to 80% of the total course delivery. A blended course may have components delivered via traditional face-to-face; however, at least half of the course delivery is online.

course_description: History of the Greek world (323-31 BCE) following the death of Alexander the Great, and the rise of successor states in Greece, Egypt and Asia Minor to the death of Cleopatra.
prerequisites: Notes: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

course_description: Varieties of love in Greek and Roman tragedy and comedy including romantic love and love in family relationships. Works include Sophocles' Antigone;Euripides' Helen and Alcestis; Aristophanes' Lysistrata; Terence's The Eunuch.
prerequisites: Notes: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

course_description: Power and conflict in the domestic and political spheres in Greek and Roman tragedy and comedy. Works may include Aeschylus' Oresteia; Sophocles' Oedipus the King; Euripides' Bacchae; Aristophanes' Birds; Plautus' The Braggart Soldier.
prerequisites: Notes: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

course_name: Art&Architecture of Roman Republic & Early Em
course_description: Art and architecture of the cultures of the Italian peninsula, in the first millennium BC, within the framework of cultural change and external influences.
prerequisites: Notes: one credit from CLAS or VISA 1Q98 and 1Q99 recommended. This course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

course_name: Art & Architecture of the Roman Empire
course_description: Roman art and architecture from Augustus to Late Antiquity. Christian art and architecture and the influence of Roman aesthetics on the Renaissance and beyond.
prerequisites: Notes: one credit from CLAS or VISA 1Q98 and 1Q99 recommended. This course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

course_name: Gender & Society in Ancient Mediterranean Cul
course_description: Ancient constructions of femininity and masculinity and their relationship to the social, political and legal systems of the Greco-Roman world. Cultural regions vary.
prerequisites: Crosslisting: also offered as HIST 3P61 and WGST 3P61

course_name: Western Diasporas in the Ancient & Modern Era
course_description: Reception, presence and experience of migrant and immigrant peoples as cultural, religious and ethnic minorities in both ancient and modern times.
prerequisites: Notes: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

course_description: Ancient burial customs, concentrating on the cultures of the prehistoric Mediterranean, emphasizing mortuary theory.
prerequisites: Notes: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

course_description: Cultural attitudes towards nature and construction of identity through landscape in Roman art and literature.
